titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the U.S. Civil War Photographs Collection, 1861-1865 MS 476

publicationstmt.publisher: Woodson Research Center, Rice University, Houston, Texas

note.p: Stored onsite at the Woodson Research Center inside the vault.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-04-01 22:21:56 -0500.

did.head: Collection Summary

repository.corpname: Woodson Research Center, Rice University, Houston, Texas

did.unittitle: U.S. Civil War Photographs Collection
did.abstract: These photographs taken during the U.S. Civil War reflect a wide range of battles and sites, although not all are represented. The collection includes 84 photographs mounted on 8″ × 91/2″ boards, many labelled with caption information. The photographs were taken by a variety of photographers, including Mathew B. Brady and Alexander Gardner, and many have been published in "The Photographic History of the Civil War" or which are also available through the National Archives.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: These photographs document the U. S. Civil War, 1861-1865.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These photographs taken during the Civil War reflect a wide range of battles and sites, although not all are represented. The collection includes 84 photographs mounted on 8″ × 91/2″ boards, many labelled with caption information.

The photographs were taken by a variety of photographers, including Mathew B. Brady and Alexander Gardner. Whenever possible they have been identified as to artist by comparison with "The Photographic History of the Civil War" and The Mathew B. Brady Collection of Civil War Photographs cited at the end of the list.

The "Photo" numbers are those which appear in pencil on the photograph itself, and the "(PHCW) Page #" reflects the page number of "The Photographic History of the Civil War" (PHCW) on which the photograph was published. Mathew B. Brady photographs are also assigned numbers by the National Archives, B-xxx, and will be so designated here.
Identifications made May, 1978. Margaret R. Olvey
Inventory divisions follow those used in "The Photographic History of the Civil War." main stacks E468.7.M5
Identifications of Mathew B. Brady photogaphs made by comparison to The Mathew B. Brady Collection of Civil War Photographs microfilm, in four reels from the National Archives, Film E 468.7 .B8.

Identifications of other photographs made by comparison to "The Photographic History of the Civil War." ed. Francis Trevelyan Miller. New York. Review of Reviews Co. 1911-12. 10 vols. reprinted in 5 vols. by T. Yoseloff, New York, 1957.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: No access restrictions; this material is open for research.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Photographs may not be duplicated without consulting with U.S. National Archives for copyright information.
Permission to publish material from the U.S. Civil War Photographs Collection must be obtained from the National Archives, through the Woodson Research Center, Fondren Library.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Gift of Mrs. George R. Brown, 1958.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: U.S. Civil War Photographs Collection, 1861-1865, MS 476 Woodson Research Center, Fondren Library, Rice University

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Stored onsite at the Woodson Research Center inside the vault.

did.unittitle: Series I: Portraits
Scene in Pleasant Valley, MD. Alex Gardner, Photographer, Plate 24." Gardner's Photographic Sketch Book of the Civil War.
Breaking Camp, Brandy Station, Negative by James Gardner, Positive by A. Gardner, Plate 63. Gardner's Photographic Sketch Book of the Civil War.
Photo of house with 20ish people in front on the balcony and front step.
Photo of small house with 6 generals/army officers in front of it. On front porch, mostly holding swords.
General Ambrose Burnside, Different Pose, with staff - Burnside sitting surrounded by ~20 men mostly standing. Outside of a tent.
Solider and Citizen Before the Appomattox Court House. Photographic History of the Civil War, Miller, Volume 9: Poetry and Eloquence, Pg. 127.
The Forces at last Join Hands. Photographic History of the Civil War, Miller, Volume 3: The Decisive Battles, Pg. 89.

McLean's House, Appomattox Court-House, Va. Where the Capitulation was Signed Between Generals Grant and Lee, Negative by T. H. O'Sullivan, Positive by A. Gardner, Plate 99. Gardner's Photographic Sketch Book of the Civil War. Also Pg. 109 of War Photographs Taken on the Battlefields of the Civil War - Mathew B. Brady and Alexander Gardner.
Aiken House, Petersburg, Virginia

Photograph Taken While Government Provision Trains were Entering Petersburg after Evacuation. Pg. 99 - War Photographs Taken on the Battlefields of the Civil War Mathew B. Brady and Alexander Gardner.
Photograph Taken at Grapevine Bridge over the Chickahominy. Pg. 40, War Photographs Taken on the Battlefields of the Civil War Mathew B. Brady and Alexander Gardner.
Castle Murray, Near Auburn, Va., Negative by T. H. O'Sullivan, Positive by A. Gardner, Plate 47. Gardner's Photographic Sketch Book of the Civil War.
Dedication of Monument on Bull Run Battle-Field. Negative by W. Morris Smith, Positive by A. Gardner, Plate 100. Gardner's Photographic Sketch Book of the Civil War.
Scouts and Guides to the Army of the Potomac, Berlin, Md. Alex Gardner, Photographer, Plate 28. Gardner's Photographic Sketch Book of the Civil War.

Photograph Taken Shortly After the Battle of Chancellorsville - Major-General Joseph Hooker and Staff. War Photographs Taken on the Battlefields on the Civil War Mathew B. Brady and Alexander Gardner.
Portrait of 7 soldiers standing or sitting with weapons on a porch
Portrait of 19 men sitting or standing in front of a staircase
Series II: Battles
Photograph Taken While Skeletons of Dead Soldiers Were Being Removed Several Months After Battle of Cold Harbor. Gardner's Photographic Sketch Book of the Civil War, Plate 94

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Photographs in this publication attributed to Mathew B. Brady and Alexander Gardner.
